section.title: Intro and Overview
section.para: This document attempts to document the eXist implementation of ProX. In doing so, it also documents ProX itself. The intention here is that the reasonably XML-savvy implementer can, efter reading through the relevant parts, install and run his or her own ProXist environement.

itemizedlist.para: Since most XML people I know of want to do it rather than read about it, here's a list of requirements...

listitem.para: For now, a modified Calabash JAR; this is available for download at the official ProXist Github site. I expect this to change soon so you can use the standard Calabash download instead.
The ProXist web app for eXist. This will give you the XQueries, XForm and such, but not the ProX XProcs, XQ, etc. Blame me; I packaged them separately.
The ProX package including wrapper XProcs, XSLT and XQ, not to mention the basic ProX blueprint, the resource map template XML, and so on. This is why you need this documentation.

For running the ProXist demo I ran at XML Prague 2014, the COSML package containing a Relax NG schema, XProc pipelines and XSLT stylesheets. COSML is simply a schema, RelaX NG these days but originally a DTD that was and is my private general-purpose XML for documentation purposes
Except, obviously, this document. . The XProc and XSLT are for doing various things with COSML documents.

section.title: Installation

procedure.para: To get the basic ProXist demo running, follow these steps:

step.para: Install eXist 2.1 or later. TBA: Calabash module.
Configure eXist with whatever packages you need, such as a PDF rendering engine if you require something else than FOP. Instructions at Wikibooks - Wolfgang - TBA.
Get the modified Calabash JAR at XXX and replace the standard JAR in XXX.
Unpack the ProX and COSML packages in XXX and XXX. If you want to place them elsewhere, you need to edit XXX with the new paths.
Unpack the example COSML files in XXX. Again, if you change the path, you need to edit XXX.
Create a temporary output collection path. This is where ProXist will place whatever files it creates. For now, give it generous permissions (I use rwxrwxrwx but that's because the NSA hates me).
Edit resource-map-template.xml for any changes done in the previous steps.

section.para: You should now be done.

procedure.para: To make sure that your shiny new ProXist installation works, try these steps:

step.para: From the eXist dashboard, hit the ProXist button. The Web app should open in a separate tab or window, depending on your browser setup.

Select a COSML XML input file and hit Generate resource map. The XML should be a root file, basically meaning that it uses the cos element as root. It's kind of nice if it's modularised in some way, because the demo becomes more fun, but not strictly necesary.
Select a process, pipeline and output in the fancy GUI. Hit Save and run child process. There should be some kind of output placed in XXX and a link to that effect displayed right under the button.

note.para: While it is theoretically possible to select an input file just once and then run several processes in sequence, selecting a new one once the previous has completed, this is not always reliable. I fully intend to fix this.

section.title: A ProX Overview
section.para: ProX, basically, is an XML-based abstraction layer that describes XProc pipelines in a system context. Think of it as the Calabash command line expressed as XML, but expanding on it to define whatever resource (XProc, XSLT, XQ, XML...) the pipeline uses in that system as packages linked to by the XML. For example, there is a script element that will link to a package element that contains some metadata plus an element with the actual link to the XProc script. If the pipeline uses an XSLT stylesheet divided into a dozen modules, the command line XML includes a link to that package, again with some metadata and tha list of links to the XSLT modules. One or more of these links also identifies any entry points to the XSLT package.
And so on. The ProX XML is a complete list of everything the pipeline is allowed to do in the system.

But ProX takes things fiurther than that. The pipeline, in ProX speak, is part of a process that may include other pipelines. For example, you might have a print publishing process that includes pipelines for PDF output, Word output, WordPerfect output (well, maybe not), and so on.

Looking at the pipeline element's command line, a single pipeline may be configured in a number of ways, withy different stylesheets, different inputs and options, engine config, and so on, so each pipeline accepts one or more command lines or cmdline elements, each of these describing their own set of bindings, configuration, and so on.
Here's an illustration of the basic ProX structure, expressed as a mind map: Basic ProX Structure

A ProX XML document describing all possible processes, pipelines and their configurations in a given system is what I call a ProX blueprint, something that lists everything that this particular system can do. Not just one pipeline using one set of configurations, but every possible pipeline configuration.
To describe a specific process using a specific pipeline with a specific configuration, selections must be made in the blueprint to narrow it down:

Now, since the ProX blueprint is an XML file, it is easy to provide it as input to an XForm allowing the end user to make the selections using a GUI rather than an XML editor. Here's the ProXist GUI: The ProXist GUI

Once every possible selection has been made in the GUI, the results can be saved into what I call a ProX instance, something that describes a single process, a single pipeline and a single configuration. No ambiguity; every choice has been made. If this instance is given runtime values (such as the URI to the input document, the name of the output, etc), it becomes an XML version of a ready-to-run Calabash shell script that runs the actual publishing process.

A simple XSLT can do that. The first ProX implementation was basically a file folder in htdocs on an Apache server and the XSLT target then was a shell script if Linux or Mac, and a batch file if Windows. In ProXist, the target document is an XQuery rather than a shell script, but the principle is unchanged.

The process selected by the user is what I call a child process. The child process was intended to be self-contained, meaning that whatever it does is black-boxed; we don't need to know what it does, we only need to know that it finished as intended. Unfortunately, in ProXist, currently, this is not the case. For more on this, see XXX.

For now, the child process returns XML markup containing whatever results that were produced by the child process. This is saved by the parent process, and sometimes also postprocessed, depending on what the markup is.

itemizedlist.para: ProX (and ProXist) uses various components that I thought better to list before attempting to explain anything else. Here goes:

listitem.para: The ProX blueprint is an XML file adhering to a Relax NG schema that describes every process, pipeline and configuration allowed in some arbitrary context, usually a system. It also lists any packages used by the pipelines (or rather, the configurations of these pipelines). These packages consist of one or more links to the actual files included by that package.

The blueprint also includes packages that define any other resources used by ProX, such as any wrapper scripts or the XForm that presents the blueprint to an end user. Basically, if ProX uses something, it should be included in the blueprint. If a child process uses something, that something should be included. You get the idea.

The resource map is an XML file that maps the actual locations of the resources defined in packages. It also lists the URIs of any input XML and the URIs of any and all outputs. The latter is, for now, generated by an XSLT but would in a proper system be decided by an external function.

ProX was born in a system that linked things using URNs rather than URLs, which necessitated a lookup mechanism to map the fixed URNs to the temporary URLs the participating resources would get when processed, usuall in a temp folder on a server somewhere. The lookup, then, consisted of a URN to URL map in a simple XML format.

Some things in the map didn't have URNs so they were identified for ProX purposes with ProX IDs. These values, made up when writing the ProX blueprint, fill pretty much the same purpose as the URNs: they provide an abstraction layer, in other words, avoiding addresses and preferring names.
The ProX IDs may or may not survive in future versions, but for now, they do have a purpose, which is to help look up things needed by ProX.

The reosurce map template is a resource map containing those resources that are considered to be static in a system, meaning that they are not determined at runtime. Therefore, every child process resource is listed in it, as is every ProX resource. What isn't is the input and the output, since these can only be determined at runtime.

The ProX XForm is an XHTML file containing some exciting XForms markup. In ProX, it was merely the ProX process/pipeline/config selection mechanism; in ProXist, it also includes an input selection mechanism. The XForm references the ProX blueprint, prox-blueprint.xml, in an XForm model instance to provide its selections to the end user. While the blueprint is statically determined in ProXist (a nicer way to say that it's hard-coded in the XForm), the blueprint URI should be added to the XForm at runtime
It was, in the original ProX demo, but time constraints made me drop this particular feature in the first ProXist version. The feature was in the XProc wrapper, but unfortunately that wrapper now runs after the XForm. , as it is listed in resource-map.xml. This is not hard to do.
The input XML is listed using an XQuery, list-resources.xq, referenced by the XForm.

The ProXist XForm uses an XQuery, gen-resmap.xq, to generate a resource map XML file based on the input XML that is selected, plus the resource map template. The XQ runs an XSLT, doc-resources.xsl, that as of this writing is somewhat specific to the COSML XML used in the demo, since it assumes XLink-based links that use the linking elements inset, block-inset and graphics to include modules. If another XML format was used for input, say, DocBook or DITA, a different XSLT would have to be written to handle XIncludes and such. This shouldn't be very hard to do, so I'm probably going to do it at some point.

The second part of the XForm, the ProX selection mechanism, uses an XQuery, save.xq, to save the ProX instance as selected by the user, and then runs the XProc wrapper script. When the XProc is done, save.xq saves the results (hence the name, but you probably guessed that, right?) and, sometimes, post-processes them. This last bit happens if the output is XSL-FO; the XQuery then runs the PDF rendering engine.

The XProc wrapper is, as the name suggests, a wrapper pipeline that first converts the ProX instance to something it can run, and then runs that something. This is where the actual child process runs, in other words. The child should return well-formed, and sometimes valid, XML that reflects the actual resulting contents, for now.

note.para: In an ideal world, the XML that is returned should merely be a URI to the result, but the current state of affairs in eXist, in particular the Calabash module or perhaps Calabash itself, stops the child from running things like the xsl-formatter XProc step, whoch means that if PDF is desired, it will have to be created after the child process, not during it.

listitem.para: The wrapper XProc uses an XQuery, ch-mode.xq, that changes the ownership, group and permisisons for the XQuery that has been generated from the ProX instance. This is done so the XQ can be executed in eXist. This, of course, is an ugly hack but reflects the author's skills perfectly. A better way to do it would be to have save.xq and whatever it runs with well-defined permissions for the purpose.
In addition, ProX (obviously) uses whatever resources that are needed by the child processes it defines.

procedure.para: Mostly for historical reasons but also because things can be learned from it, here's the basic steps of the first ProX demo (Balisage 2013):

step.para: Start the wrapper XProc pipeline.This runs the whole ProX chain, from start to finish, and the idea was for it to be a black box that ran another black box, that is, the child process. Hence the names wrapper and child, even though parent might have been a better term. Never mind.

procedure.para: ProXist, on the other hand, is not a monolithic wrapper process, encapsulating everything in a black box. Rather, it is a two-stage process loosely held together by the XForm that displays the ProX UI.

section.title: Processes
section.para: The root element of the schema is the processes element that may contain (you guessed it) one or more process elements, each of which is meant to describe a process within the system.
Here's the process structure: The process Element

section.title: Pipelines
section.para: A process is an abstract grouping of related pipelines. They could be print publishing, web publishing or shopping lists, or basically anything the designer of the system considers to be a meaningful group in the context of the current system. It's an abstraction, but the pipelines it groups are actual pipelines.
Here's the pipeline element: The pipeline Element

section.title: Command Lines
section.para: A pipeline may be configured in a number of ways, with different options and input and whatnot, depending on what the pipeline is for, and so a command line as represented by the cmdline element in the ProX schema is simply one such configuration of that pipeline.
Here's the cmdline element: The cmdline Element
Here's the input element: The input Element
TBA inputs are port/value pairs; params may be defined for an input that points out a stylesheet; params are port/value pairs ...
TBA values: types of values (pkg, external, uri, string, other) and their uses

section.title: Packages
section.para: Packages are groups of related files used as one unit by a process. The XProc script itself, be it one file or several, can (and should) be defined as a package. The XSLT stylesheets used by XProc pipelines are normally modularised and split into several separate files, but should be defined as a package. And so on.

note.para: If the stylesheets use images to, for example, output a standardised page footer, the images should be part of the stylesheet package as well.

section.para:
Packages provide convenient grouping of related files, ensuring that all participating files are included. A package is intended to be a bit more than that, however: Firstly, if the system hosting the files can provide links to specific versions of each file
The system from which ProX originates uses URNs rather than URLs when linking. The URNs contain not only a unique name but versioning and language/country information for a specific incarnation of that name, so in that system, the URN will always identify a unique, identifiable version of a resource. , the package will list a number of varying versions of the participating files while ensuring that the specified versions can work together as a unit.

Secondly, if the package is an XSLT stylesheet, it may list allowed and configurable parameters for the stylesheet, including the allowed values (and value types) for each parameter. See XXX (cmdline ref) for details.
Here's the package element: The package Element
The locator element provides an XLink to a package resource using a URI. In ProXist, the link is a URL pointing out an eXist resource.

section.title: Metadata
section.para: Processes, pipelines, command lines and packages include a metadata structure containing a title and a description. The title should be short and descriptive, as it is used in the ProX XForm GUI, mostly in dropdown lists. The description should be a slightly longer description of the purpose of whatever the metadata describes; the ProX XForm uses it to display popups with context-sensitive information.

note.para:
At some point hopefully reasonably soon, I intend to add metadata structures to the param XSLT parameter definitions in the Relax NG schema. Frequently, XSLT parameters are user-configurable
Even though ProXist does not currently support this, because of limitations in the Calabash eXist module. and rather than providing the frequently rather cryptic parameter names (toc.depth, etc), it would be nice to use proper metadata for the user interface.

section.title: Authoring ProX Blueprints
section.para: Authoring a ProX blueprint is, while not for the faint of heart, not impossible, either. The first thing to remember is that it models a typical Calabash command line, but unlike one, it includes every binding allowed in the system the ProX blueprint is meant to describe.

The second thing to remember, then, is simply that the blueprint is really just a a long list of configurations for a system: this process allows these two pipelines, which in turn allow these command lines linking to these stylesheet packages with these possible parameters... ProX is a definition language, and everything it defines has to do with processes in a system that do something with XML stored and handled by that system.

section.title: The Resource Map XML Format
section.para:
The resource map is a well-formed XML file used for lookups. It is generated during the first step of the ProX wrapper process, after selecting an input file, and uses the input to list the input file and whatever modules it may use, and to generate runtime target file names
This particular feature works, meaning that target names are created, but they are unfortunately not used by the wrapper XQuery because of limitations in what a child process can and cannot do inside eXist, given the current Calabash eXist module. . It also lists any resources used by ProX, but these are static and are already defined in a resource map template.
